Comment: Key points:  Ukraine and the US reached a landmark mineral resources deal, announced on April 30, 2025, in Washington.  The agreement establishes a 50/50 investment fund for Ukraine’s reconstruction, with both countries sharing oversight equally.  Ukraine will contribute future earnings from mineral licenses (not current resources or infrastructure); the US contribution is new aid, not previous assistance.  The fund is required to invest in Ukrainian reconstruction and infrastructure for at least 10 years.  Tariffs between the US and Ukraine on relevant goods are reduced to zero, and the US will seek additional investors for the fund.  The US gains access to Ukraine’s critical minerals (including graphite, titanium, lithium, and rare earths), but Ukraine retains full control over its subsoil and resources.  The deal’s final signing is pending ratification by Ukraine’s parliament; only the framework was signed so far.  Security guarantees for Ukraine were discussed but not finalized; President Zelensky continues to push for them as part of the agreement.  The original US proposal, which demanded $500 billion in mineral revenue, was dropped in favor of more balanced terms for Ukraine.  The agreement is seen as a step toward incentivizing continued US support for Ukraine and deterring future Russian aggression.  In parallel, US officials are pressing Ukraine to accept a ceasefire plan freezing current front lines, but Ukraine has not agreed to this peace proposal.
